title: Architect spends 45 years converting dilapidated World War One cement factory into his home… and the result will amaze you
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THIS jaw-dropping house was once a World War One-era concrete factory before an architect spent 45 years turning it into his home. 
Ricardo Bofill fell in love with the huge derelict concrete structure, which is near Barcelona, in 1973. Ricardo Bofill The building started life as a concrete factory Ricardo Bofill 12 What was once a brutal structure is now dripping with greenery 
Over the decades Bofill and his team added lush vegetation and turned it from an industrial shell into a unique work of art – La Fabrica. 
Bofill said: “Seduced by the contradictions and the ambiguity of the place, we quickly decided to retain the factory, and modifying its original brutality, sculpt it like a work of art. 
“Presently I live and work here better than anywhere else. It is for me the only place where I can concentrate and associate ideas in the most abstract manner.” Related stories Forget the London property bubble - house prices are rising MORE in Liverpool and Birmingham MAKING ROOM ON THE BUS Family of five tired of pricey rents convert school BUS… but have to cope with frozen pipes LIGHTHOUSE FAMILY Stunning lighthouse on remote Scottish island that comes with three family homes on sale for £275,000 HOME FIT FOR A QUEEN Church clock tower once owned by the Queen and now converted into a family home goes on the market for £1.8million HOUSE OF GOD Inside the divine £600,000 home converted from a CHURCH - and it comes with its own stained glass windows Ricardo Bofill It has been a project in the making for more than four decades Ricardo Bofill “It is for me the only place where I can concentrate,” he said Ricardo Bofill The awe-inspiring property is near Barcelona Ricardo Bofill 12 The interior is elaborate but retains the bare concrete walls 
The exterior is covered by grass, eucalyptus, palm, and olive trees and gives the impression that the property has been partially reclaimed by nature. 
Every room is uniquely furnished but he kept the raw concrete walls as a “memory of the structure’s former use”. Ricardo Bofill A central hallway in the monolithic structure Ricardo Bofill The architect has retained the brutal lines of the building Ricardo Bofill The kitchen-dining room located in the ground floor is the meeting point for the family Ricardo Bofill Bofill describes his living room as “Domestic, monumental, brutalist and conceptual” Ricardo Bofill Each room is uniquely decorated Ricardo Bofill 12 La Fabrica is also a studio for his team 
He added: “I have the impression of living in a precinct, in a closed universe which protects me from the outside and everyday life. 
“Life goes on here in a continuous sequence, with very little difference between work and leisure. 
“I have the impression of living in the same environment that propelled the Industrial Revolution in Catalonia.” 
As well as acting as his home and offices, the main factory hall has been turned into a conference room.
